snippet.textDisplay:
Oculus doesn't care about anything, apparently. They don't even do the effort, like Steam, to sell their DIGITAL copies of games worldwide. I understand why they don't ship the actual headsets worldwide, but not even selling the games ? They're just stupid. Don't they want money ? To buy from their store I have to either have an international Credit card or PayPal, which also needs an International Credit card because it's in Dollars.

From Steam, I can pay with my own currency on any bank of my country, or with a normal debit card in my own currency and NOT in Dollars, which would make things waaaaaay more expensive because of the conversion rates.
snippet.textOriginal:
Oculus doesn't care about anything, apparently. They don't even do the effort, like Steam, to sell their DIGITAL copies of games worldwide. I understand why they don't ship the actual headsets worldwide, but not even selling the games ? They're just stupid. Don't they want money ? To buy from their store I have to either have an international Credit card or PayPal, which also needs an International Credit card because it's in Dollars. 

From Steam, I can pay with my own currency on any bank of my country, or with a normal debit card in my own currency and NOT in Dollars, which would make things waaaaaay more expensive because of the conversion rates.

snippet.textDisplay: I think I would opt into the RTX 2070. If its already struggling with 1060 then there's no room for a more demanding VR game... when they come out. I don't want to invest that much money into a graphics card only to have it become obsolete the second the new VR games come out. That being said, I'm still 4 months away from purchasing, possible building, my own gaming rig. I just purchased the Oculus Rift... I tend to be a more casual player, but also like to play headline titles like HFA. For me the Quest + Link made the most sense. I'm hoping that they come out with updated software to make the experience smoother.
snippet.textOriginal: I think I would opt into the RTX 2070. If its already struggling with 1060 then there's no room for a more demanding VR game... when they come out. I don't want to invest that much money into a graphics card only to have it become obsolete the second the new VR games come out. That being said, I'm still 4 months away from purchasing, possible building, my own gaming rig. I just purchased the Oculus Rift... I tend to be a more casual player, but also like to play headline titles like HFA. For me the Quest + Link made the most sense. I'm hoping that they come out with updated software to make the experience smoother.

snippet.textDisplay: Any chance a GTX 1050 ti or a GTX 1650 could support the game on low settings? I haven’t gamed in a long time, but I’m a huge HL fan and would love to play. I have a pretty cruddy computer (refurbished HP Compaq Elite 8300 sff) that’s been used primarily for music production, but hoping there might be a cheap upgrade that would enable me to play. I’m limited in my options as a low profile GPU is necessary and I’m constricted to 240W PSU and 25W GPU. I also have an i7-3770 @ 3.40GHz and 16GB of RAM. Any insight that anyone could offer would be greatly appreciated!

snippet.textDisplay: So I guess it looks like the low end sweet spot here would be at least a GTX 1660 Super, team orange represented by RX 5600XT or the older RX 590 8gb on the GPU side and a decent 6 core CPU that can hold/sustained 3.8 to 4.2ghz respectively, then pairing one of those GPUs with either the $900 Vive Pro or the $1K+ "MacDaddy" of VR Valve's Valve Index set up..."It sounds like it'll be a long while before I'm getting a chance to enjoy a true AAA VR game" :/

snippet.textDisplay:
I know this has nothing to do with the video but i need help with my pc and this is the only place i could think of to ask. Adding a new cpu to a prebuilt.

So last august i bought a pre-built. It was a good deal because it was basically the same price to build with the same parts. It has a Asrock A320M-HDV motherboard,8 gb of DDR-4, 600w PSU, rx560, and a ryzen 3 2300x. I am looking to upgrade the cpu to a ryzen 5 1600. But i am not sure if the 1600 is compatible since they are different generations. If anyone could help i would appreciate it.
snippet.textOriginal:
I know this has nothing to do with the video but i need help with my pc and this is the only place i could think of to ask.                                       Adding a new cpu to a prebuilt.

So last august i bought a pre-built. It was a good deal because it was basically the same price to build with the same parts. It has a Asrock A320M-HDV motherboard,8 gb of DDR-4,  600w PSU, rx560, and a ryzen 3 2300x. I am looking to upgrade the cpu to a ryzen 5 1600. But i am not sure if the 1600 is compatible since they are different generations. If anyone could help i would appreciate it.

snippet.textDisplay:
The quest is amazing I got one last year this year. For a while I was using a cloud computer to play vr and it impressed me and worked for a while. But I never realized how much the latency was until I finally got a pc. I’m still using virtual desktop to stream to the quest eventually I’ll check out the link but it already feeels so good wireless I don’t want to be plugged in.

I think the bottom line is, if you start with the quest and work up you’ll be pleased with every upgrade but if you’re used to a higher quality you may notice something I don’t know that doesn’t apply to me so everything feels great

snippet.textDisplay:
Hi guys,

I would like to know your opinion about this PC spec:

Intel i7-7800X
ASUS PRIME X299-A
RX 5700XT 8GB
Corsair Vengeance RGB Pro 3200MHz 64GB DDR4(Kit 8x8GB)
M.2 SSD: Samsung 970 EVO PLUS 250GB
M.2 SSD: Samsung 960 EVO 250GB
2,5” SSD Samsung 860 EVO 250GB
2,5” HDD Seagate Laptop Thin 500GB

all in Lian Li PC-O11. PC is water-cooled. All components are still under warranty.

My friend can sell me this PC for a very reasonable price. He wants to switch from PC to NB because of work.

Can this spec run flawless VR? Im very interested in VR but on budget, so buying used PC can get me more power for the same price. Im planning to buy Oculus Rift S. Really looking forward to try out beat saber, alyx, vrchat and other great games. Non VR games run with no issue at all.

None of us have VR headset so we ran some VR Benchmarks. Here are the results:

SteamVR Performance Test: Average Quality - Very High (11) 0% frames below 90%
VRMark - 7690 points - Average fps : 167,63
Superposition - 1st test (shaders - optimum, textures - high) min. 75,57, avg. 136,58, max. 222,21 (overall 10 000 points)
2nd test (shaders - maximum, textures - high) min. 68,75, avg. 106,90, max. 146,80 (overall 9502 points)

Does anyone have experience with this kind of spec? Are these results reliable? Thanks in advance.
snippet.textOriginal:

ASUS PRIME X299-A

                            2nd test (shaders - maximum, textures - high) min. 68,75, avg. 106,90, max. 146,80 (overall 9502 points)

Does anyone have experience with this kind of spec? Are these results reliable? Thanks in advance.

snippet.textDisplay: Can you get the official link cable and stop dinking around with the anker + adapter combo? Even the party link 16 ft cable will solve your problems.
